item.title: Some good advice on how to program rsps wisely
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:7, topic:445155”][quote author=t4 link=topic=547842.msg4017021#msg4017021 date=1339719126]

You never ever want to hardcode data, unless you really have to.

With the exception of magic numbers and cases of String literals, there’s never really a good reason to hardcode something… It is much better to statically encapsulate all configuration data for subsets of the server in independent classes.

Enums are nice, as well as XML files or other database forms

databases, in the sense most people think about here, are kind of overkill for this situation. try looking into key, value structures like bdb.
[/quote]
Alright.

His hardcoded 2d array seems ridiculous also because the second value in each array is always 1 also.[/quote]
It was merely an example that I took off a random source on my computer. But it could also serve as a bad example and an addition to bad habits.

KroniKz_:

Great great great tutorial superman! Absolutely awesome I hope a lot of people will follow this.

Thanks!

Read full topic
item.source: Some good advice on how to program rsps wisely

With the exception of magic numbers and cases of String literals, there’s never really a good reason to hardcode something… It is much better to statically encapsulate all configuration data for subsets of the server in independent classes.

Enums are nice, as well as XML files or other database forms
[/quote]
databases, in the sense most people think about here, are kind of overkill for this situation. try looking into key, value structures like bdb.[/quote]

His hardcoded 2d array seems ridiculous also because the second value in each array is always 1 also.

With the exception of magic numbers and cases of String literals, there’s never really a good reason to hardcode something… It is much better to statically encapsulate all configuration data for subsets of the server in independent classes.

item.title: Some good advice on how to program rsps wisely
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:2, topic:445155”][quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=547842.msg4016926#msg4016926 date=1339715421]
I will always see a ton of code in one method piled up like crazy. If you can, you should always try to use an array to store some of that data to make it less confusing.
[/quote]
Arrays should only be really used for sequences of data… passing around Object[] args and whatnot is not the way to go. Try encapsulating data in a class that you pass around.

You also should always try to stay away from unnecessary looping, or if your code can be stopped right then and there, but continues throughout the method, you should avoid this and always stop if you really do not need to keep going. You always want your code to not put so much stress on the VM.

I wouldn’t call loops stressful… they’re more of wasted cpu cycles.

You never ever want to hardcode data, unless you really have to.

With the exception of magic numbers and cases of String literals, there’s never really a good reason to hardcode something… It is much better to statically encapsulate all configuration data for subsets of the server in independent classes.[/quote]
Thank you for that. I appreciate your comments.

Read full topic
item.source: Some good advice on how to program rsps wisely

item.title: Some good advice on how to program rsps wisely
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

imsuperman05:

I will always see a ton of code in one method piled up like crazy. If you can, you should always try to use an array to store some of that data to make it less confusing.

Arrays should only be really used for sequences of data… passing around Object[] args and whatnot is not the way to go. Try encapsulating data in a class that you pass around.

imsuperman05:

You also should always try to stay away from unnecessary looping, or if your code can be stopped right then and there, but continues throughout the method, you should avoid this and always stop if you really do not need to keep going. You always want your code to not put so much stress on the VM.

I wouldn’t call loops stressful… they’re more of wasted cpu cycles.

imsuperman05:

You never ever want to hardcode data, unless you really have to.

With the exception of magic numbers and cases of String literals, there’s never really a good reason to hardcode something… It is much better to statically encapsulate all configuration data for subsets of the server in independent classes.

Read full topic
item.source: Some good advice on how to program rsps wisely

item.title: Some good advice on how to program rsps wisely
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

Description: I will show you some ways on how to keep your code very clean, and give you advice on some programming habits.
Difficulty: Close to 2/10
Assumed Knowledge: Understandment of the basics of Java, at least.

Tested Server(s): Any and all
Files/Classes Modified: Any and all

[center][size=14pt]Keeping code clean
[/size][/center]
In PI sources, you will always see dirty code. There are ways to clean up this code with not much trouble and quick learning.

First, let’s go over what is dirty code and what is clean.

[size=10pt]Dirty:[/size]

    public void totallevelsupdate() {
	int totalLevel = (getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[0])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[1]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[2])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[3]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[4])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[5]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[6])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[7]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[8])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[9]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[10])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[11]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[12])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[13]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[14])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[15]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[16])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[17]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[18])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[19]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20])
		+ getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[21]) + getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[22]));
	sendFrame126("Levels: " + totalLevel, 13983);
    }

Code like this is very ugly and should never ever turn into a habit. This code could be simplified into a few lines, seeing as there is a certain pattern to all the incrementing. If there is ever a constant pattern that you can very well simplify, then you should always do so.

It could simplify into this easily.

Clean:

    public void totallevelsupdate() {
	int total = 0;
	for(int slot = 0; slot < 22; slot++) {
	    total += getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[slot]);
	}
	sendFrame126("Levels: " + total, 13983);
    }

You should always keep in mind that another programmer, someday, will always see your code and you want to impress that programmer as much as you can as well as keeping the same outcome of the code. Conventions are also very very important to other programmers, or newcomers. I suggest you read this link under if you do not understand what conventions are completely.
http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/documentation/codeconvtoc-136057.html

There are many more examples that I can explain about, but at the moment I cannot think of any others.

[center][size=14pt]Bad programming habits:[/size][/center]

I will always see a ton of code in one method piled up like crazy. If you can, you should always try to use an array to store some of that data to make it less confusing. You also should always try to stay away from unnecessary looping, or if your code can be stopped right then and there, but continues throughout the method, you should avoid this and always stop if you really do not need to keep going. You always want your code to not put so much stress on the VM.

[size=12pt]Example[/size]

    public void SummonNewNPC(int npcID) {
	if (c.InDung()) {
	    c.sendMessage("You can't do this in dung fucking faggot!");
	    return;
	}
	int maxhit = 0;
	int attack = 0;
	int defence = 0;
	// c.getPA().sendFrame75(c.hasFollower, 17027);

	switch (npcID) {
	case 6830:
	    maxhit = 4;
	    attack = 10;
	    defence = 80;

	    break;

	case 6826:
	    maxhit = 6;
	    attack = 10;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6842:
	    maxhit = 6;
	    attack = 10;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6807:
	    maxhit = 5;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    c.maxstore = 3;
	    c.summonTime = 1200;
	    break;

	case 6797:
	    maxhit = 8;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 7332:
	    maxhit = 8;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6832:
	    maxhit = 8;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6838:
	    maxhit = 8;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 7362:
	    maxhit = 8;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6848:
	    maxhit = 8;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6995:
	    maxhit = 10;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6872:
	    maxhit = 10;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 7354:
	    maxhit = 11;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6836:
	    maxhit = 12;
	    attack = 20;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6846:
	    maxhit = 14;
	    attack = 40;
	    defence = 80;
	    break;

	case 6808:
	    maxhit = 12;
	    attack = 40;
	    defence = 80;
	    ;
	    break;

	case 7371:
	case 7369:
	case 7368:

	case 6816:

	    maxhit = 21;

	case 6814:

	case 7372:

	case 8576:

	case 7346:

	case 6799:

	case 6850:

	case 7344:

	    attack = 90;
	    defence = 80;
	    c.summonTime = 6000;
	    break;
	}
	switch (npcID) {
	case 6830:
	    pouchreq = 0;
	    break;

	case 6826:
	    pouchreq = 4;
	    break;

	case 6842:
	    pouchreq = 10;
	    break;

	    break;
	case 6864:

	    break;
	case 6823:
	    pouchreq = 88;
	    break;
	case 7340:
	    pouchreq = 89;
	    break;

	case 6870:
	    pouchreq = 92;
	    break;

	case 7350:
	    pouchreq = 93;
	    break;

	case 7376:

	    break;
	case 6874:
	    pouchreq = 96;
	    break;
	case 7344:
	    pouchreq = 99;
	    break;
	}

	if (c.playerLevel[21] >= pouchreq) {
	    Server.npcHandler.Summon(c, npcID, c.absX, c.absY - 1,
		    c.heightLevel, 0, 100, maxhit, false, attack, defence);
	    c.getItems().deleteItem(c.s, 1);
	    for (int i = 0; i < NPCHandler.maxNPCs; i++) {
		if (NPCHandler.npcs[i] != null) {
		    c.npcslot = NPCHandler.npcs[i].npcId;
		}
	    }
	} else {

	    c.sendMessage("You need " + pouchreq
		    + " Summoning to summon this monster.");
	}

    }

Something like this could always be cleaned up or shortened or approached in a different, more effective manner.

You never ever want to hardcode data, unless you really have to.

Hardcode = the manner of a ton of excessive data in one place.

[size=12pt]Example:[/size]

    private static int[][] xEP = { { 14882, 1 }, { 14881, 1 }, { 14877, 1 },
	    { 14876, 1 }, { 892, 12 }, { 1099, 1 }, { 1165, 1 }, { 1351, 1 },
	    { 1319, 1 }, { 1333, 1 }, { 1359, 1 }, { 1149, 1 }, { 1185, 1 },
	    { 1704, 1 }, { 157, 3 }, { 145, 2 }, { 175, 4 }, { 995, 14700 },
	    { 995, 22500 }, { 6731, 1 }, { 6733, 1 }, { 4712, 1 }, { 4714, 1 },
	    { 4716, 1 }, { 4718, 1 }, { 4720, 1 }, { 4722, 1 }, { 4736, 1 },
	    { 4738, 1 }, { 4749, 1 }, { 4751, 1 }, { 892, 100 }, { 4675, 1 },
	    { 4091, 1 }, { 4093, 1 }, { 4095, 1 }, { 4097, 1 }, { 4101, 1 },
	    { 4103, 1 }, { 4105, 1 }, { 892, 100 }, { 1768, 1 }, { 892, 12 },
	    { 892, 12 }, { 4107, 1 }, { 4111, 1 }, { 4113, 1 }, { 4115, 1 },
	    { 4117, 1 }, { 4131, 1 }, { 1079, 1 }, { 14877, 1 }, { 1127, 1 },
	    { 14883, 1 }, { 14884, 1 }, { 14885, 1 }, { 14886, 1 },
	    { 14887, 1 }, { 892, 12 }, { 14888, 1 }, { 14890, 1 },
	    { 14891, 1 }, { 14892, 1 }, { 4716, 1 }, { 4734, 1 }, { 1319, 1 },
	    { 1333, 1 }, { 1359, 1 }, { 995, 1000000 }, { 892, 100 },
	    { 995, 5815 }, { 995, 10000000 }, { 1085, 1 }, { 1089, 1 },
	    { 1351, 1 }, { 14885, 1 }, { 14886, 1 }, { 14887, 1 },
	    { 14888, 1 }, { 14889, 1 }, { 14890, 1 }, { 14891, 1 } };

This is a very bad example, indeed. This is also a bad habit that some people seem to pick up from other new programmers.

eyeownyew:

His hardcoded 2d array seems ridiculous also because the second value in each array is always 1 also.

Thank you very much for your time in reading my tutorial. I have not written a tutorial in a long time, so please let me know if I left anything important out. I am open to any good/hateful comments. None of the code here is mine, with the exception of the second method posted.

Read full topic
item.source: Some good advice on how to program rsps wisely
